body_text.text: activities and global pandemic control actions. Refer to Appendix Table 2 and the reference list in the manuscript.

In addition to public information, we performed in-depth interviews to seek for experts' opinions on China's performance during the Ebola crisis in Western Africa. We conducted three interviews with the stakeholders from the China Health and Family Planning Commission, China CDC, and USCDC. The interviews are semistructured with open-end questions and the opportunities for the interviewers to explore any newly emerged ideas.

The major questions include: "Why did China put such a big effort in Africa to help with Ebola control?", "What did China's focus differ by countries?", "What difficulties did China encounter during the entire process?", "What is the composition of China's disease control teams?", "What are the comparative advantages/disadvantages of China's health assistance comparing to other countries?", "How should China CDC position itself in global health in the future?", "How was it planned for the African CDC and what are the respective roles of China CDC and the USCDC?", "What were the major lessons learned by China?"

The duration of the interviews varied between 45 and 120 min. We audiotaped all interviews, except for one interview conducted by phone. The audio records were transcribed in their entirety by an independent transcriptionist. The interviewed in Chinese were translated to English. All data were analyzed line-by-line and the main themes were identified and compared across all transcripts. We searched thoroughly for various views under each theme to allow for a full description of various factors.

Data on China's yearly development assistance for health (DAH) is very limited. Although China's State Council has produced two White Papers on China's foreign aid in 2011 and 2014, the data are without clear definition and not disaggregated by aid purpose. To estimate China's DAH, we tracked the financial flows from bilateral and multilateral channels:

We identify China's bilateral DAH by tracking projects on AidData.org: We manually screened all China's projects recorded in AidData.org, 1 and classified the projects in to two categories: "Health" and "Population and Reproductive Health". For most projects, AidData provided the titles, commitment years, short descriptions, sectors the aid flowed into and the monetary value in either US dollars or local currencies. Based on the flow classification defined by AidData's Methodology for Tracking Underreported Financial Flows (TUFF), 2 we restricted our search to official government financing, including "Official Development Assistance (ODA)-like", "Other Official Finance (OOF) Flow-like", "Official Investment" and Vague (Official Finance)".

In sum, a total number of 390 bilateral DAH projects between 2008 and 2013 were retrieved from the database. Information on these Chinese global health projects were cross-checked from various online sources, such as official websites of the Ministry of Commerce, National/Provincial Health and Family Planning Commission, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Chinese Embassies abroad, as well as news report, to ensure accuracy of the nature and financial value of the projects. After eliminating duplicate records, 387 projects were included.

Nonetheless, up to 50% of the projects (particularly among the in-kind donation projects) did not provide precise investment amount or with a vague number of total project value, in which the Chinese contribution cannot be assessed. For such projects, we categorized them into 3 types (hospital construction or renovation, health workforce enhancement and supplies of drugs and medical equipment) and substituted the missing or imprecise values using the median of the cost structure from the same type of projects during 2008-2013. For projects with multi-year commitments, the total value was divided by the project duration (normally ranges from 2-5 years) and counted toward each year's annual commitment. China's yearly DAH between 2010 and 2013 was therefore estimated by summing up the yearly commitment of all projects in that specific year.

The amount of China's multilateral DAH was estimated based on the official reports of multilateral development agencies. It mainly included aid flows from UN healthrelated development agencies, development banks in which China has shares, and other non-state institutions, such as civil societies (i.e. International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent, International Planned Parenthood Federation) and public private partnerships (i.e. the Global Fund against HIV/AIDS, Malaria and Tuberculosis). We retrieve China's annual contribution to a UN agency and the nonstate institutions from their annual financial reports between 2010 and 2013. There is no direct information about China's DAH contribution through the World Bank and other regional development banks. Nonetheless, the Institute for Health Metric and Evaluation (IHME) tracked the DAH through these banks with project-level data of all health-related projects and loans. 3 China's contribution was estimated by multiplying each bank's total DAH by China's % share in that specific bank. Appendix Box 1 shows details on the channels we tracked on China's global health contribution.

The To compare China's ODA and ODA as a share of GNI with the other countries, we retrieve annual ODA and GNI in US, UK, Japan and OECD-DAC from OECD statistics (http://stats.oecd.org/) and retrieve DAH in these countries from IHME website (www.healthdata.org). China's annual ODA was estimated by Kitano et al in 2014. 4 To compare the DAH flow between China and USA by source-channel-focus, we retrieved the US data from the latest IHME Report on global health financing 3 . The sources of China's bilateral and multilateral DAH data have been introduced above. Unlike the detailed project descriptions in the IHME database, China's DAH projects are usually described in a vague way, such as "hardware investment". We categorized these projects into two types: "health infrastructure" (including infrastructural projects of various kind of clinics, medical centers and other healthcare-related facilities) and "health supplies, technical support and training" (including delivering health services, drug donations, providing technical assistance, human resource training) For comparative analyses of China's banks and funds, and the World Bank, we retrieved total capitalization and investment profiles from the latest annual reports of the World Bank, Asia Development Bank, and African Development Bank. For China's banks and funds, we retrieved the capital bases of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, the New Development Bank, Silk Road Fund, China-Africa Development Fund and South-South Cooperation Fund from the official websites and news reports.
